Initially, after the board is read, they compute:

clean =0
q, r = divmod(cnt, n)
for j in range(q):
    for i in range(n):
        clean += board[i][j] == '*'

for i in range(r):
    clean += board[i][q] == '*'

So the clean is the number of stars in the first q full columns and the first r rows of column q. 

When the count changes, the q and r change, so the clean needs to be updated. But recalculating this from scratch each time would be O(nm), which is too slow for q up to 2e5. Hence, the code must have an efficient way to track this.
